docs.lead_paragraph: WEST SAN QUENTIN, CALIF.: INMATE EXECUTED -- Robert Lee Massie, California's longest-serving condemned inmate, was put to death by lethal injection minutes after midnight, despite a last-ditch effort by opponents of capital punishment. Mr. Massie, convicted of murders in 1965 and 1979, had abandoned his own appeals to protest the slow pace of the state's death row, and his last words were, ''Forgiveness: giving up all hope for a better past.'' Todd S. Purdum (NYT) ROCKIES

docs.lead_paragraph: One doctor performed an unneeded hysterectomy on an ailing patient without giving her a routine checkup; she had a problem with her lungs. New York State proclaimed another doctor an imminent danger after he botched baby deliveries. A third doctor cleared patients for surgery without examining them. These doctors have three things in common: all practiced medicine at a New York City hospital; all were disciplined by the state for negligence; and then all easily found work again. Two of them are still treating patients today.

headline.main: MEDICAL RETREADS: A special report.; Doctors Punished by State But Prized at the Hospitals

docs.abstract: Special report, Medical Retreads, focuses on ease with which doctors, disciplined for negligence by New York State, find work at other hospitals or are retained by hospital where problems occurred; neither state nor federal government lays out how hospitals should handle such doctors, nor does national organization that accredits hospitals; many New York hospitals routinely hire and retain doctors with bad records, especially those who bring in lot of money; hospital administrators, often doctors themselves, argue that almost every doctor who errs deserves second chance, or even third, and many receive them, sometimes moving from hospital to hospital between punishments for negligence or incompetent care; state data indicate more than three-fourths of doctors disciplined over last eight years resumed working almost immediately after state punished them, and that 285 who were disciplined kept medical licenses from 1992 until 1999; State Health Department officials, criticized for failing to revoke medical licenses, say complicated disciplinary system makes it hard to do so; argue that hospitals share responsibility to weed out bad doctors, but that they lack specific rules on hiring and monitoring doctors punished by state; health care policy experts say hospitals are hardly pressed to make do with troubled doctors in New York City, where ratio of doctors to population is 50 percent higher than national average; state data show, however, that doctors with disciplinary problems are often among top third of moneymakers at their hospitals; charts; photos (L)

docs.lead_paragraph: Sitting on a leopard-print couch in a house that shudders as planes land at nearby Miami airport, Ady Solis cannot quite put her finger on when her childhood began to slip away. In her pudgy face and nervous giggle, there are still signs of the girl she should be at 16, but just barely. Gone are the days when she was simply somebody's little girl, somebody's promising pupil.

headline.main: Troubling Label for Hispanics: 'Girls Most Likely to Drop Out'

docs.abstract: Article on troubling implications of data showing that 26 percent of Hispanic girls drop out of school, compared with 13 percent of black girls and 6.9 percent of white girls; Hispanic boys have even higher dropout rate, 31 percent, compared with 12.1 percent for black boys and 7.7 for white boys; Hispanic girls also leave school earlier than any other group and are least likely to return; photos; graph; Repr Ileana Ros-Lehtinen sees 'confusion' in 'young Latina psyche'; Hispanic researchers note regional differences between subgroups, with many Mexicans and Central Americans coming to US with very little schooling; also point to teenage pregnancy and family demands; girls themselves say they get mixed messages about schooling versus getting married and having children (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: SECOND GRADE is not all fun and games. So after a full day at school, Olivia Annacone, 7, of East Hampton takes a yoga class. ''School is stressful,'' Olivia said recently, pressing her hands and feet onto the floor as she lifted her hips in the air in a yoga position called ''down dog'' that is said to release tension and strengthen the back and hamstring muscles.

headline.main: For Relief of Childhood Stress, Try Yoga

docs.abstract: Long Island Journal column: YMCA recreation center in East Hampton, opens yoga classes to help local children release stress; Deborah Oppenheimer, daughter of Kindertransport survivor, is nominated for Academy Award for best documentary, Into the Arms of Strangers, which documents stories of Jewish children evacuated from Germany, Austria and Czechoslovakia to safety in England during World War II; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: ON the surface, THE UMBRELLAS OF OCHERBOURG (1964) seems about as good as Peter Bogdanovich's ''At Long Last Love'' or Steven Bochco's ''Cop Rock.'' But for reasons that are part of the mystery of filmmaking, this pretty French romance, in which all the dialogue is sung, is a gem. It probably doesn't hurt that the star is a luminous newcomer, the 20-year-old Catherine Deneuve, or that Michel LeGrand wrote such gorgeous music. It's the story of very young, beautiful lovers, the draft notice that separates them, the girl's concerned mother, an out-of-wedlock pregnancy at a time when that was a problem and a handsome diamond merchant visiting town, capped with a ''Splendor in the Grass'' ending that could tear your heart out. It won the Cannes Film Festival's top prize, the Palme d'Or. Nino Castelnuovo plays Ms. Deneuve's young love interest; Jacques Demy wrote and direted - Wednesday at 12:45 p.m. on TM.

docs.lead_paragraph: THE AMERICAS CANADA: RESIGNATION SOUGHT -- Prompted by the release of new information, opposition leaders accused Prime Minister Jean Chrétien of a conflict of interest and of concealing the truth, and called for him to step aside. The opposition has alleged for months that the prime minister pressured federal officials to approve a $390,000 loan for a failing hotel in which he held a 25 percent stake, though Mr. Chrétien has said that he sold his interest in 1993 before talking to officials. Toronto newspapers have now reported that Mr. Chrétien was listed on ownership records after he took office in November 1993. Anthony DePalma (NYT) GUYANA: RULING PARTY WINS -- Guyana's governing party has won a third consecutive term after racially charged elections that prompted accusations of fraud and touched off riots. According to official results, Monday's vote returned to power President Bharrat Jagdeo and his People's Progressive Party, which is largely backed by Guyanese of East Indian descent. (AP)

docs.lead_paragraph: There must be a few things, artistically, that the polymath German artist Rosemarie Trockel can't do. But what she does do has not escaped notice. She knits. She paints. She makes photographs and videos. She does sculpture and installations. And all the while she keeps on drawing -- often wittily, sometimes weirdly and always with wild diversity. It's easy to say what her work on paper is not about: the traditional notion of drawing as representation. Metaphorical, enigmatic, ambivalent and punning, her drawings blend mischief, whimsy and corrosive humor. They are often deliberately rough and unfinished, not to say clumsy. They catch the human in animals and vice versa, comment on gender, observe body structure and gesture, play off the work of other artists. To make them, she uses tools and techniques that run from felt-tipped pens to computers, photocopying machines and digital technologies.

headline.main: Drawings as Enigmas Wrapped in Metaphors

docs.abstract: Grace Glueck reviews exhibitions of works by Rosemarie Trockel at Drawing Center and Barbara Gladstone Gallery; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: FACING THE WIND A True Story of Tragedy and Reconciliation By Julie Salamon 302 pages. Random House. $24.95. What parent of a healthy, exhausting toddler hasn't wished from time to time that the little buzz saw had come equipped with an off switch? But suppose one were faced with a daunting alternative: A baby too sick to move. A baby born without eyes. A baby so brain-damaged that it cannot even be coaxed to smile. This is the world that Julie Salamon explores in her painful, poignant ''Facing the Wind: A True Story of Tragedy and Reconciliation.''

headline.main: When a Parent's Most Frightening Nightmare Turns Out to Be Just the Beginning

docs.abstract: Teresa Carpenter reviews book Facing the Wind: A True Story of Tragedy and Reconciliation by Julie Salamon; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The Supreme Court ruled today that hospital workers cannot constitutionally test maternity patients for illegal drug use without their consent if the purpose is to alert the police to a crime. The court's 6-to-3 decision did not resolve a 10-year-old lawsuit brought against the city of Charleston, S.C., by women who were arrested, under a cooperative program between a public hospital and the police department, after a positive urine test for cocaine.
docs.abstract: Supreme Court rules, 6-3, that hospital workers cannot constitutionally test maternity patients for illegal drug use without their consent if purpose is to alert police to crime; majority opinion by Justice John Paul Stevens is strong statement that facts of women's pregnancy and of possible danger to their fetuses through illegal drug use does not change basic constitutional analysis: in absence of either warrant or consent, drug tests amount to unconstitutional searches; Justice Antonin Scalia writes dissenting opinion, joined by Chief Justice William H Rehnquist and Justice Clarence Thomas; decision does not resolve 10-year-old lawsuit brought against city of Charleston, SC, by women who were arrested, under cooperative program between public hospital and police department, after positive drug test; question of whether any of 10 plaintiffs actually consented to tests remains to be decided in lower courts; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The most comprehensive study yet of the levels of potentially harmful substances in Americans has some encouraging findings, and sometimes surprising ones. The results published yesterday by federal health officials showed, for example, that nonsmokers' exposure to cigarette smoke is one fourth what it was in 1991, as measured through levels of cotinine.

headline.main: Study of Chemicals in Americans Shows Encouraging Trends

docs.abstract: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention publishes most comprehensive study yet of levels of potentially harmful substances in Americans; finds levels of mercury in children are lower than expected, and well below federal limits, but that mercury concentrations in women of child-bearing age are higher than expected, though not above current limits; finds nonsmokers' exposure to cigarette smoke is one fourth what it was in 1991; study is first to measure wide range of chemicals in body instead of relying on estimates; this sets stage for major shift in way agencies concerned with environment, food and health determine risks posed by byproduces of industrial age; chart (M)
